SENT.plain: A 30-year-old female developed moyamoya syndrome after gamma knife surgery (GKS) for cerebral arteriovenous malformation (AVM), and was treated with bypass surgery
She suffered from flittering scotoma, right transient hemianopsia, and headache for 1 year
Cerebral angiography revealed a Spetzler-Martin grade III AVM located in the left occipital lobe
After staged embolization, GKS was performed with a minimum dose of 20 Gy to the periphery of the nidus at the 50% isodose level of the maximum target dose
Gradual nidus regression was achieved, and the clinical symptoms disappeared completely
However, at 30 months after GKS, the patient suffered transient ischemic attack
Cerebral angiography showed left middle cerebral artery occlusion with moyamoya vessels
The patient underwent direct and indirect bypass surgery
After surgery, the patient was free from ischemic symptoms
Chronic inflammation and long-term changes in expression of cytokines and growth factors after GKS may have triggered this case
